<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 880, 636]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 664, 212, 678]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 680, 728, 711]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 75.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 94, 93]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 75, 918, 95]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(y = 5 + 3x - 2x^2\) and a straight line has equation \(y = kx + 13\), where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 107, 675, 126]]<|/det|>
Find the set of values of \(k\) for which the curve and the line do **not** meet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 107, 918, 126]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 138, 918, 952]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[85, 71, 101, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[349, 83, 645, 339]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 354, 918, 396]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve with equation \(y = 2x^{2} - \frac{5}{x} + 3\) . The curve crosses the \(x\)-axis at the point \(P(1, 0)\) and \(M\) is a minimum point.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 408, 146, 427]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 408, 430, 427]]<|/det|>
Find the gradient of the curve at \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 408, 920, 427]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 621, 148, 640]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 621, 777, 640]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of \(M.\) Give each coordinate correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 621, 920, 640]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 94, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 82, 144, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 78, 484, 102]]<|/det|>
Find the complete expansion of \(\left(2x - \frac{3}{x}\right)^4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 82, 920, 101]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 108, 920, 536]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 547, 148, 565]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 541, 749, 567]]<|/det|>
Hence determine the coefficient of \(x^{2}\) in the expansion of \(\left(x^{2} + 5\right)\left(2x - \frac{3}{x}\right)^{4}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 545, 920, 565]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 573, 920, 945]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 72, 102, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[368, 83, 626, 265]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 281, 828, 299]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a triangle \(OAB\) where \(OA = OB = 10 \text{cm}\) and angle \(AOB = 0.8\) radians.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 297, 918, 330]]<|/det|>
Points \(C\) and \(D\) on \(OA\) and \(OB\) respectively are such that the arc \(CD\) is part of a circle with centre \(O\) and radius \(6 \text{cm}\). The shaded region is bounded by the arc \(CD\) and the line segments \(CA\), \(AB\) and \(BD\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 345, 146, 363]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 345, 470, 363]]<|/det|>
Find the perimeter of the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 345, 920, 363]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 655, 146, 673]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 655, 428, 673]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 655, 920, 673]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 653, 88]]<|/det|>
An arithmetic progression has first term 5 and common difference 6.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 103, 737, 120]]<|/det|>
For this progression, find the sum of all the terms that lie between 150 and 400.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 103, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 133, 917, 952]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[384, 88, 611, 263]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 280, 918, 330]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a circle \(C\) of radius \(r\), where \(x > 0\) and \(y > 0\) for all points on \(C\). The least distance between any point on \(C\) and the \(x\)-axis is 8 units, and the least distance between any point on \(C\) and the \(y\)-axis is 5 units.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 344, 146, 361]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 343, 626, 361]]<|/det|>
State the coordinates of the centre of the circle in terms of \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 343, 918, 361]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 405, 148, 422]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 405, 918, 437]]<|/det|>
Given that the distance between the origin and the centre of the circle is 15 units, find the value of \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 420, 918, 438]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 700, 146, 718]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 700, 650, 718]]<|/det|>
The point on the circle furthest from the origin is denoted by \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 731, 539, 749]]<|/det|>
Find the gradient of the tangent to the circle at \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 731, 918, 749]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 826, 91]]<|/det|>
A geometric progression is such that its second term is \(-120\) and its sum to infinity is 160.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 106, 146, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 106, 341, 123]]<|/det|>
Find the common ratio.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 106, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 138, 917, 463]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 475, 148, 494]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 475, 600, 494]]<|/det|>
The first nine terms of the progression are now removed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 508, 672, 526]]<|/det|>
Find the sum to infinity of the remaining terms of the progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 508, 920, 526]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 541, 917, 925]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 85, 94, 104]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 75, 836, 112]]<|/det|>
A curve is such that \(\frac{\mathrm{d}^2y}{\mathrm{dx}^2} = \frac{6}{x^4} - \frac{5}{x^3}\). It is given that the curve has a stationary point at \(\left(\frac{1}{2}, 9\right)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 123, 148, 145]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
Use the expression for \(\frac{\mathrm{d}^2y}{\mathrm{dx}^2}\) to determine whether the stationary point is a maximum or a minimum point.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 153, 920, 172]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 308, 148, 327]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 308, 920, 327]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the curve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 308, 920, 327]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 343, 920, 945]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 104, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[348, 88, 656, 291]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 308, 460, 325]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve with equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 337, 591, 357]]<|/det|>
\[y = 4(3x + 4)^{\frac{1}{2}} - 2x - 6\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 370, 917, 419]]<|/det|>
for values of \(x\) such that \(0 \leqslant x \leqslant 7\). The tangent to the curve at the point \(P\) (7, 0) meets the \(y\)-axis at the point \(Q\). Region \(A\) is bounded by the curve and the two axes. Region \(B\) is bounded by the curve, the line segment \(PQ\) and the \(y\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 433, 146, 450]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 433, 357, 450]]<|/det|>
Find the area of region \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 433, 918, 450]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 104, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 72, 546, 90]]<|/det|>
Functions f and g are defined for all real values of \(x\) by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[358, 101, 640, 120]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = 4x^{2} - c\quad \mathrm{and}\quad \mathrm{g}(x) = 2x + k\,,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 133, 653, 151]]<|/det|>
where \(c\) and \(k\) are positive constants. It is given that \(\mathrm{g}^{-1}(3k + 1) = c\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 165, 146, 182]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 164, 395, 182]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\mathrm{gf}(x) = 8x^2 - k - 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 165, 920, 182]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 196, 917, 928]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 77, 146, 95]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 77, 918, 110]]<|/det|>
The curve with equation \(y = 8x^{2} - k - 1\) is transformed to the curve with equation \(y = \mathrm{h}(x)\) by the following sequence of transformations.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 113, 339, 149]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{Translation~of~}\binom{2}{3}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 149, 522, 184]]<|/det|>
Stretch in the \(y\)-direction by scale factor \(k\) Reflection in the \(x\)-axis

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 197, 527, 216]]<|/det|>
Find an expression for \(\mathsf{h}(x)\) in terms of \(x\) and \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 197, 918, 216]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 505, 144, 524]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 505, 450, 524]]<|/det|>
The range of \(\mathsf{h}\) is given by \(\mathsf{h}(x) \leqslant 15\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 537, 363, 556]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(c\) and \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 537, 918, 556]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]
